title: Today in Apple history: Fans line up to get their hands on the very first iPhones
description: On June 29, 2007, the first iPhone launch date arrived. Apple fans lined up to buy the original iPhone, offering a preview of things to come. (via Cult of Mac - Your source for the latest Apple news, rumors, analysis, reviews, how-tos and deals.)
author: Luke Dormehl
excerpt: On June 29, 2007, the first iPhone launch date arrived. Apple fans lined up to buy the original iPhone, offering a preview of things to come.
text: Apple history The smartphone that changed smartphones! Photo: Traci Dauphin/Cult of Mac June 29, 2007: The first iPhone launch date arrives, giving excited Apple fans lined up outside stores their first chance at owning the game-changing smartphone. The queues that greet the device around the world prove that Cupertino is onto a good thing with the smartphone, first shown off by Apple CEO Steve Jobs earlier in the year. The launch-day fervor offers a glimpse of just how revolutionary the iPhone will become. First iPhone launch date: Apple fans line up for June 29, 2007 These days, queuing up for (or getting up early to preorder) the latest “insanely great” product is a part of Apple culture, just like that sly sense of superiority every time you hear your Android-owning friend complain about malware. But it wasn’t always like this. In the late 1990s, a series of mini Apple stores inside larger tech retailers bombed horribly because of a lack of foot traffic. By 2007, things had changed radically. A preview of frenzies to come By the time of the first iPhone launch date, Apple Stores were opening around the world, fulfilling Apple CEO Steve Jobs‘ vision of an upscale retail outlet. Plus, a string of iconic products — the colorfully “toyetic” Bondi Blue iMac, the equally bright iBook laptop, the iPod and its iconic white earbuds — had transformed Apple into a brand that could create a genuinely ardent opening-day buzz. These devices proved cool enough to queue up for. And that’s exactly what happened when the iPhone first went on sale on a Friday in late June 2007, as Knocked Up and Pixar’s Ratatouille ruled theaters and Amy Winehouse’s “Rehab” dominated the radio waves. iPhone launch-day lines: An Apple tradition is born Around the United States, news outlets reported snaking lines of customers waiting to pay $500 or $600 a pop for a new iPhone. “We’ve been in line for days,” Melanie Rivera, a customer outside Apple’s SoHo store in New York City, told CNN Money. “It’s very uncomfortable out here in these chairs. But people are very social. We’ve made it through the rain, so we feel like we’re getting closer to the phone.” Similar scenes played out in other major cities on the date the first iPhone launched. To build anticipation, Apple limited each customer to just two iPhones. AT&T, meanwhile, said it would sell just one handset per person. For any bemused non-techies watching on TV, perhaps the most exciting moment was when tech journalist Steven Levy — one of a small number of writers to get his hands on a device prior to launch — almost got mugged on live television. The first iPhone: An unproven entity Not everyone was sure about the iPhone when it launched on this day in 2007, however. Apple already proved it could create non-computer products with the enormously successful iPod. But 2007-era Apple remained only a decade removed from the scattershot company that tried to get into the video game, digital camera, pocket organizer and, yes, restaurant markets during the 1990s. Simply put, some people remained skeptical about Apple. With the iPhone’s lack of 3G connection, poor-quality camera, AT&T exclusivity and high price point, they weren’t totally wrong to maintain their skepticism. In a research note to clients, Tom Smith, Universal McCann’s research manager for Europe, the Middle East and Asia, wrote: “The simple truth [is that] convergence is a compromise driven by financial limitations, not aspiration. In the markets where multiple devices are affordable, the vast majority would prefer that to one device fits all.” Universal McCann’s appraisal matched its research, which suggested only 31% of Americans wanted a device with multiple capabilities. Chatter in the queue on the first iPhone launch date There’s no doubt the first iPhone launch prompted big lines in certain places. Still, one Apple fan recalls that day as surprisingly laid-back — certainly when compared to the massive events that accompanied later Apple product launches. “Queues today are much, much larger,” Mark Johnson, a 56-year-old graphic designer from Liverpool, England, told Cult of Mac in 2017. “I knew that I wanted the iPhone as soon as it was announced, so on launch day I queued at the Trafford Centre Apple Store. I was fairly near the front of the queue, and when I arrived, I was surprised that there weren’t more people.” Johnson does, however, recall the type of excited launch-day chatter that will feel familiar to anyone who ever queued up for a new Apple product. “The people at the launch speculated how it would affect them and change their lives,” he said. “Some thought it would just be a phone that plays music, with a few extras, but as Apple fans were buying it anyway. Others thought — quite rightly — that it would be a game-changer.” Do you remember the original iPhone launch? In recent years, Apple took steps to discourage long lines like the ones on this date in 2007 for the first iPhone launch. These days, hordes of online shoppers plunk down credit cards to preorder the latest Apple gear the moment it goes on sale. Many opt for delivery rather than pickup, but iPhone launch days remain festive occasions in Apple stores. Were you one of the folks queuing up for an original iPhone? Dredge up your memories of the iPhone launch and share them in the comments below. We originally published this post on the original iPhone launch on June 29, 2017.
html:
• Apple history

June 29, 2007: The first iPhone launch date arrives, giving excited Apple fans lined up outside stores their first chance at owning the game-changing smartphone. The queues that greet the device around the world prove that Cupertino is onto a good thing with the smartphone, first shown off by Apple CEO Steve Jobs earlier in the year.

The launch-day fervor offers a glimpse of just how revolutionary the iPhone will become.

First iPhone launch date: Apple fans line up for June 29, 2007

These days, queuing up for (or getting up early to preorder) the latest “insanely great” product is a part of Apple culture, just like that sly sense of superiority every time you hear your Android-owning friend complain about malware.

But it wasn’t always like this. In the late 1990s, a series of mini Apple stores inside larger tech retailers bombed horribly because of a lack of foot traffic. By 2007, things had changed radically.

A preview of frenzies to come

By the time of the first iPhone launch date, Apple Stores were opening around the world, fulfilling Apple CEO Steve Jobs‘ vision of an upscale retail outlet.

Plus, a string of iconic products — the colorfully “toyetic” Bondi Blue iMac, the equally bright iBook laptop, the iPod and its iconic white earbuds — had transformed Apple into a brand that could create a genuinely ardent opening-day buzz.

These devices proved cool enough to queue up for. And that’s exactly what happened when the iPhone first went on sale on a Friday in late June 2007, as Knocked Up and Pixar’s Ratatouille ruled theaters and Amy Winehouse’s “Rehab” dominated the radio waves.

iPhone launch-day lines: An Apple tradition is born

Around the United States, news outlets reported snaking lines of customers waiting to pay $500 or $600 a pop for a new iPhone.

“We’ve been in line for days,” Melanie Rivera, a customer outside Apple’s SoHo store in New York City, told CNN Money. “It’s very uncomfortable out here in these chairs. But people are very social. We’ve made it through the rain, so we feel like we’re getting closer to the phone.”

Similar scenes played out in other major cities on the date the first iPhone launched. To build anticipation, Apple limited each customer to just two iPhones. AT&T, meanwhile, said it would sell just one handset per person.

For any bemused non-techies watching on TV, perhaps the most exciting moment was when tech journalist Steven Levy — one of a small number of writers to get his hands on a device prior to launch — almost got mugged on live television.

The first iPhone: An unproven entity

Not everyone was sure about the iPhone when it launched on this day in 2007, however. Apple already proved it could create non-computer products with the enormously successful iPod. But 2007-era Apple remained only a decade removed from the scattershot company that tried to get into the video game, digital camera, pocket organizer and, yes, restaurant markets during the 1990s.

Simply put, some people remained skeptical about Apple. With the iPhone’s lack of 3G connection, poor-quality camera, AT&T exclusivity and high price point, they weren’t totally wrong to maintain their skepticism.

In a research note to clients, Tom Smith, Universal McCann’s research manager for Europe, the Middle East and Asia, wrote: “The simple truth [is that] convergence is a compromise driven by financial limitations, not aspiration. In the markets where multiple devices are affordable, the vast majority would prefer that to one device fits all.”

Universal McCann’s appraisal matched its research, which suggested only 31% of Americans wanted a device with multiple capabilities.

Chatter in the queue on the first iPhone launch date

There’s no doubt the first iPhone launch prompted big lines in certain places. Still, one Apple fan recalls that day as surprisingly laid-back — certainly when compared to the massive events that accompanied later Apple product launches.

“Queues today are much, much larger,” Mark Johnson, a 56-year-old graphic designer from Liverpool, England, told Cult of Mac in 2017. “I knew that I wanted the iPhone as soon as it was announced, so on launch day I queued at the Trafford Centre Apple Store. I was fairly near the front of the queue, and when I arrived, I was surprised that there weren’t more people.”

Johnson does, however, recall the type of excited launch-day chatter that will feel familiar to anyone who ever queued up for a new Apple product.

“The people at the launch speculated how it would affect them and change their lives,” he said. “Some thought it would just be a phone that plays music, with a few extras, but as Apple fans were buying it anyway. Others thought — quite rightly — that it would be a game-changer.”

Do you remember the original iPhone launch?

In recent years, Apple took steps to discourage long lines like the ones on this date in 2007 for the first iPhone launch. These days, hordes of online shoppers plunk down credit cards to preorder the latest Apple gear the moment it goes on sale. Many opt for delivery rather than pickup, but iPhone launch days remain festive occasions in Apple stores.

Were you one of the folks queuing up for an original iPhone? Dredge up your memories of the iPhone launch and share them in the comments below.

We originally published this post on the original iPhone launch on June 29, 2017.
